DataElement.preferredName: Stage Prognostic Factor Commission on Cancer Pediatric Neoplasm Stage Code
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Code for stage of pediatric tumor in an AJCC stage scheme, a pediatric intergroup study scheme, or a pediatric cooperative group scheme.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Stage Prognostic Factor Commission on Cancer Pediatric Neoplasm Stage
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Pediatric tumor in an AJCC stage scheme, a pediatric intergroup study scheme, or a pediatric cooperative group scheme.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.:The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Concepts.definition: The extent of a cancer in the body.
The general personal and health characteristics that have a bearing on the course of a disease and its eventual outcome.

Property.preferredName: Commission on Cancer Pediatric Neoplasm Stage
Property.preferredDefinition: A consortium of professional organizations dedicated to improving survival and quality of life for cancer patients through standard-setting, prevention, research, education, and the monitoring of comprehensive quality care.:Having to do with children.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: A consortium of professional organizations dedicated to improving survival and quality of life for cancer patients through standard-setting, prevention, research, education, and the monitoring of comprehensive quality care.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The extent of a cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.

DataElementConcept.origin: NAACCR:North American Association of Central Cancer Registries

ValueDomain.preferredName: Commission on Cancer (COC) Pediatric Neoplasm Stage Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Commission on Cancer (COC)_Having to do with children._(TOO-mer) An abnormal mass of tissue that results from excessive cell division. Tumors perform no useful body function. They may be benign (not cancerous) or malignant (cancerous)._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body._A system of numbered categories for representation of data. [Explanatory Comment: See the ROADS Manual for allowable codes.]

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
